title: 107_hr3509
content: The "Retirement Account Protection Act of 2001" may be cited as the Act. It includes additional fiduciary protections related to lockdowns under employee stock ownership plans. The "Retirement Account Protection Act of 2001" provides fiduciary protections regarding lockdowns in eligible individual account plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. No lockdown can be imposed without written notice and exemption from the Secretary. The Secretary may grant exemptions for lockdowns in eligible individual account plans under the "Retirement Account Protection Act of 2001" if it is administratively feasible, in the interests of the plan and its participants, and protective of their rights. Interested persons must be notified and given the opportunity to present views before an exemption is granted. Compliance with the exemption requirements is necessary for a plan to be exempt from lockdown restrictions. The term "lockdown" in retirement plans refers to restrictions on transferring accrued benefits from employer securities to other investment options, excluding permanent limitations on employer contributions or reasonable transfer frequency restrictions. SEC. 3. STUDY RELATING TO CAPS ON INVESTMENT OF INDIVIDUAL ACCOUNT PLAN ASSETS IN EMPLOYER SECURITIES. The Secretary of Labor, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury and the Securities and Exchange Commission, will conduct a study on the investment of plan assets in employer securities. The study will consider statutory limits on such investments and analyze feasibility with various limits. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Labor will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for statutory or administrative changes based on the study results on plan assets investment in employer securities. The effective date and related rules are outlined in Section 4. The amendments made by this Act apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 2002, with a special rule for collectively bargained plans to adjust the effective date based on collective bargaining agreement termination dates. The amendments made by this Act apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 2002, with a special rule for collectively bargained plans. Plan amendments are not required before the first plan year beginning on or after January 1, 2004, if the plan is operated in accordance with the Act's requirements during the interim period.
